hobby.message: The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It is quiet, yes. Not that I mind.
I keep busy with small projects at home.
Origami mostly. Helps pass the time.
It's harder lately with everything going on.
Yeah. I usually fold origami after work.
Paper folding, I mean. Makes the quiet easier.
Finding materials is tricky with recent disruptions.
Blackout the other day messed with my routine.
Had to improvise with scraps I found.
Quiet suits me. I unwind with origami most evenings.
Folding shapes out of scrap paper helps me focus.
Been tougher to find good paper since the blackout.
System memos make decent cranes but not clean lines.
Crowds near the metro make it hard to relax lately.
I still manage a few models when things settle at night.
I actually spend a lot of evenings doing modular origami at home.
Paper folding clears my head when things get too tense.
After the blackout, all my clean paper was useless—had to use official notices.
Weird how city events change little routines like that.
I made a box out of system memos. Felt strange but necessary.
If things get noisy outside, the process gives me some control.
I started keeping finished models hidden lately.
Origami’s been my steady habit since I joined the Directorate—keeps my mind organized.
When the blackout hit, all I had left was BCI paperwork to fold.
Folding modular stars out of flagged documents feels... symbolic now.
After hearing about the mural, I nearly went, but I folded instead.
It’s strange: what used to be just stress relief now feels risky.
Sometimes I hide my models so no one asks questions if there's an inspection.
Even the paper I use gets recorded somewhere. Makes you careful.
Origami still gives me order when nothing else does, even if I have to disappear pieces.
hobby_answer: Yeah, something small. Just a fold or two.
Dont carry much now. Never know who looks.
Papers harder to come by after the blackout.
People notice little things these days.
Sticking to basics until things stabilize.
Made a quick crane, nothing fancy.
Usually I use receipts, but those disappeared after last week.
Everyones tense since the mural, avoids anything unusual.
Used an old report sheet. Seemed safe enough.
Not the time for big projects, I guess.
Don't want anyone asking why I'm folding.
Actually, yes. Folded a star from system memos after the blackout.
Strange how the power cut made everyone lock up their drawers.
Had to get creative with discarded office papers.
Feels risky now. Even a hobby seems suspicious after the mural thing.
Used to leave models around the block. Dont anymore.
Colleagues are shredding everything, even scratch notes.
Hard to enjoy it while everythings so exposed.
Got a new box, folded from an old appeal response after my badge failed.
Funny, lately its only the confidential printouts left lying around.
The blackout shook everyone, and then the mural happened.
Used to swap origami quietly with a friend down the hall.
Now shes off the roster, and I hide every piece I make.
Folding calms me when systems scramble, but its harder to relax.
Folded up the last model and stuck it away, just in case.
Feels like were all packing bits of ourselves away lately.
Brought a modular crane, hidden in my bag. Cant risk leaving it out.
Since the metro mural, everyones shredding everything. Origami gets you questions.
Used to practice intricate folds from confiscated BCI warnings. Irony, right?
I miss leaving little models for neighbors... now it marks you as odd.
The blackout gave everyone an excuse to purge. Papers become... sensitive.
Sometimes I remake the same fold three times, anxious someone is watching.
Saw someone get queried for doodling in the stairwell. Nobody trusts harmless hobbies.
I fold because it keeps me steady, but now it just makes me hide.
Lately, I feel like every model is a secret flag. Dont know how long Ill keep it up.
